items.title: Canada's economy sees surprise boost in 3rd quarter, avoiding a technical recession
items.summary_auto: The Canadian economy grew at an annualized rate of 2.6 per cent in the third quarter, Statistics Canada said on Friday, avoiding a technical recession largely due to a surge in defence spending.

items.title: Trump vows to further clamp down on migration from developing nations after D.C. attack
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday his administration will "permanently pause" migration from all "Third World Countries," following an  attack near the White House  he attributed to Biden-era immigration vetting failures.

items.title: Flood deaths in Southeast Asia reach 321 as rescuers step up recovery operations
items.summary_auto: The death toll from floods across large swaths of Southeast Asia rose to at least 321 on Friday, with authorities working to rescue stranded citizens, restore power and communications and co-ordinate recovery efforts as the waters began to recede.

items.title: If you want to shop ethically this holiday season just buy less, Guelph prof says
items.summary_auto: While it’s not always easy to shop with workers rights, animal welfare and the environment in mind, a University of Guelph professor says many customers want to support products made in Canada, with fair labour, or using environmentally-friendly practices.

items.title: ‘Cash for keys’ offers are making people homeless, say housing advocates in northern Ontario
items.summary_auto: Housing advocates in the northern Ontario city of Sudbury say “cash for keys” agreements are making people homeless over the long term.

items.title: Jamaican farm workers in N.S. prepare to head home to hurricane devastation
items.summary_auto: Jamaican farm workers in Nova Scotia are bracing for a difficult time when they return to their home country still reeling from the devastating impact of Hurricane Melissa.

items.title: Military family inspires some young Canadians to enlist, despite recruitment hurdles
items.summary_auto: Against a backdrop of increased tensions with the U.S. and dismal labour prospects for young Canadians, some students are looking to the military for their future careers. They tell CBC News why the Canadian Armed Forces has captured their interest and where they're at with recruitment.

items.title: 'Tis the season for holiday shopping. But are Canadian products on the list?
items.summary_auto: Despite recent data suggesting the Buy Canadian movement is losing steam, some business owners are hopeful the boom they've been seeing will continue through Black Friday sales and throughout the holiday shopping season.

items.title: Some commercial lobster fishers say Indigenous treaty fishing threatens stocks. Government memo says otherwise
items.summary_auto: The fifth estate investigates misconceptions and allegations fuelling conflict in Canada’s largest lobster fishery, where Mi’kmaw fishers face broad opposition when exercising treaty rights.

items.title: Why the White House blames National Guard shooting on program that brought Afghan nationals to the U.S.
items.summary_auto: The Trump White House is blaming Operation Allies Welcome, a Biden-era program that brought thousands of Afghan nationals to the U.S., for bringing the suspect in Wednesday's National Guard shooting to the U.S. Here's what we know about the program.

items.title: Government demanding public servants reimburse years-old Phoenix overpayments
items.summary_auto: Federal public servants are being threatened with legal action if they don’t repay money they were mistakenly overpaid during the error-plagued rollout of the Phoenix pay system nearly a decade ago, Radio-Canada has learned.

items.title: The Carney-Smith agreement surely won't make pipelines 'boring again'
items.summary_auto: Guilbeault's resignation — the rare cabinet resignation due to a disagreement over government policy — both adds to and underlines the test of national and political leadership that Mark Carney signed up for when he put his signature on that memorandum.

items.title: Can Canadians still trust Canada Post with holiday mail after months of strikes?
items.summary_auto: Technically, the rotating Canada Post strikes are over. But can Canadians trust the corporation to get their Christmas cards and packages delivered on time? Here's what to know.

items.title: Molson Canada accuses ex-managers of multimillion-dollar fraud scheme
items.summary_auto:
Molson Canada has accused former managers of embezzling millions of dollars in an intricate fraud scheme allegedly involving
fake vendors, shell companies, the president of a major pub chain and a pair of married couples.

items.title: #TheMoment a wrong number in the group chat forged new friendships
items.summary_auto: Three friends tell The National about the moment a wrong number added to their group chat turned into years of friendship.

items.title: 'The answer is still no': B.C. chiefs react to new pipeline agreement
items.summary_auto: Alberta Premier Danielle Smith and Prime Minister Mark Carney signed an agreement to make way for a new bitumen pipeline from the Alberta oilsands to the B.C. coast. 'We will use every tool in our toolbox to ensure that this pipeline does not go ahead,' said Heiltsuk Nation Chief Marilyn Slett.

items.title: Lake Erie shipwreck spotted off Kingsville, Ont., uncovered by strong winds
items.summary_auto: Strong winds that prompted an Environment Canada alert this week have laid bare shoreline not often seen. But they also uncovered a rarely-seen shipwreck near Kingsville.

items.title: Annual Inuit Christmas party in Ottawa to be completely virtual
items.summary_auto: Inuit in Ottawa say they're disappointed by a local organization's decision to host their annual Christmas party completely online this year.

items.title: New trial ordered for Ontario man who spent 23 years in prison for 10-year-old girl’s murder
items.summary_auto: Ontario’s court of appeal has set aside a conviction and ordered a new trial for a man who spent 23 years in prison for the murder of a 10-year-old girl in 1989 — but by all accounts, it’s unlikely that trial will ever happen.

items.title: Latest fiscal update shows Alberta’s budget deficit holding steady at $6.4B
items.summary_auto: The outlook for Alberta's budget in its second-quarter update remains largely unchanged from the previously grim forecast provided in August.

items.title: Ontario signs nearly $40M deal with another First Nation in Ring of Fire region
items.summary_auto: As part of its ongoing plans to develop in the mineral-rich Ring of Fire region, the Ontario government has signed a community partnership agreement with Marten Falls First Nation. Here's how the agreement builds on other deals the province has made with communities in the region, and why some First Nations are critical of the province's fast-tracked development approach.

items.title: 3 Calgary police officers accused of sexual misconduct involving 7 women
items.summary_auto: Three Calgary police officers have been charged with criminal offences linked to allegations of sexual misconduct involving seven women, one of whom was allegedly photographed while partially naked and in custody.

items.title: Ticketmaster will partially refund fans of singer Olivia Dean after she called out 'vile' reselling
items.summary_auto: 'The prices at which you’re allowing tickets to be re-sold is vile and completely against our wishes,' U.K. musician and breakout star Olivia Dean said of Ticketmaster on Instagram last week. Ticketmaster and parent company Live Nation said they’ll limit the ability to resell tickets above face value going forward, and will refund fans the difference.

items.title: Pilot dies in small plane crash near Nanaimo, B.C., on Vancouver Island
items.summary_auto: Sealand Flight Ltd., a flight training school based in Campbell River, B.C., said one of its pilots died in the crash, which involved a Sealand Flight Cessna 172 on a private flight.

items.title: Ottawa police to share RIDE locations in advance
items.summary_auto: Ottawa police are taking a new approach to their annual holiday season RIDE campaign — they're letting drivers know in advance where the sobriety checkpoints will be.
